Hey guys
So I want to use Rx into my app. Since this is my first time diving in to Reactive, where do I start if I want to observe any changes that's happening in a SharedPreference?

<@U0SNJDQDC>: pretty simple, make a SharedPreferencesListener class, "bind" it to your SharedPreferences, wrap it all in an observable roughly speaking. If you are just starting with Rx, it's best to read up on the documentation and try setting up an app which uses some kind of REST api for displaying data
Here is a free ebook that I found very good
<http://www.oreilly.com/programming/free/rxjava-for-android-app-development.csp>

attachments.title: RxJava for Android App Development - O'Reilly Media
attachments.text: RxJava is hot property among experienced Android developers these days, but this powerful library for handling asynchronous data in Android apps can be difficult to learn. In this O’Reilly report, mobile software engineer Matt Dupree introduces you...

re camera query - if you can get away with minsdk 21 def go with Camera2

also notice that each time I call this method it hault the UI for 2-3 sec before we can the response

I wish the general public just knew how shitty samsung phones actually are
<@U0UEQSNMC>:  very true even inside samsung each version behave differently like some stuff dont work in Note 4 or 5 while works on s5 and s6
May be you should try call `public void setPictureSize (int width, int height)` to change default picture size.
<@U0C7F00AH>:  yes I have tried that its just sometimes on some device its make the photo squeeze and the qaulity is never same like the camera app
I think i might use 3rd party lib for this.
If you don’t call setPictureSize, system well use default size to take picture.
that will be picture size based on what camera hardware support right?
and not the mobile height and width

yes, you can see this method declare:

```java
public List<Camera.Size> getSupportedPictureSizes ()

Gets the supported picture sizes.

Returns
a list of supported picture sizes. This method will always return a list with at least one element.
```
cool thanks
and this dont need camera 2 api right
you are welcome.
Can startActivityForResult not be called outside of an activity class
can, fragment
Anyone has any good resources on caching paginated results? I have made an implementation on a side project that I'm working on but I have a feeling that I over-engineered
can you just use standard http cache?
just out of curiousity
haven’t actually tried it yet

Nope. To be honest I'm doing this more of a practice, I'm playing around with the TwitterSdk, fetching tweets based on filters, caching them, using the paginated api with network or the paginated cache without network etc.
right
<@U09T8SFG8> LruCache ? Page number as the key and list of tweets as value.
Or did you mean persistent? :simple_smile:

<@U0QR1SM32>: I made an in-memory cache for another part of my project that I needed (simpler than LRU because it was all I needed). Now I'm trying to do a persistent one. Basically I retrieve some tweets from the network which are paginated (with minimum and maximum tweet id because that's how Twitter's REST API likes it) and every time I'm fetching them I persist them to the storage (the db). Now if the user tries to access without a network connection, I simply want to start serving him with paginated disk results (from the db) until he gets back on the network.

I am more interested in the software design patterns used with it, I am heavily using the repository pattern along with proxy, strategy and decorator but things are getting a bit crazy and I believe I can do things simpler
Why don't you just serialize the adapter every time you Assign another and next time load it back from dB or raw file
If network not available
I would do that but I want to mix network with disk if necessary. For example: fetchFromNetwork(0, 50) -> fetchFromDb(50, 100) -> fetchFromNetwork(100, 150)
I think you may need to use loader manager then
means the loader which first load data from DB but also in back ground load from the network if there is difference it refresh the adapter
I think google+ does that way
Hmmm I see, I'll look up on that, thanks!

text: <@U060Q7J2Y>: I thought AutoValue was clunky because your classes need to be abstract, don’t like the static `create()` method, don’t like having to reference a generated class from the `create()` method.  adds more complexity to your app when it’s not hard to use intellij’s built-in generators.
I also don’t trust plugins like AutoParcel to write efficient parceling code
no, its not hard to use the generators. but you need to remember to update them every time you change a field. which is error prone
easier to remember that than all of the AutoValue conventions
I don’t like the idea of depending on an IDE I could replace at any moment
if someone was so careless to make an error like that I’m not sure I’d want to work with them lol.  also, code reviews.
value types are nice though, hopefully they come to Android in the future :confused:
easier to remember to regenerate a whole bunch of stuff manually, than not doing anything at all?
humans are very error prone during repetitive tasks
true, but it’s not really a repetitive task. how often do your value types change?  I’ll write them once and maybe update them every couple months.
and then it’s just like performing normal, responsible refactoring
even more likely to forget if you don’t do it often!
parcel code is especially brittle too. order matters, etc.
well parceling code should have tests supporting it
or just, you know, let the machine do it

text: maybe it’ll help you

again, worst case scenario, you implement what you can’t in kotlin in java and can still reuse these classes from kotlin :simple_smile:
it used to be the case for all custom views for a long time
back when kotlin didn’t support multiple constructors :simple_smile:
I’m afraid that’s going to have to be the case
I’ll give it a try
but if the generics aren’t working in the baseactivity class, they won’t work in my activity either
so then I’m back to writing everything in java ><
It seems to really just be a triple generics deep problem tho
I htink you shouldn’t have nested generics in normal classes??
it’s just the base classes that are problematic
or I’m missing something
`abstract class BaseActivity<V : MvpView, P : MvpPresenter<V>, C : MvpComponent<P>> : MvpActivity<V, P>(), MvpView `
`class MainActivity : BaseActivity<MainView,MainPresenter,MainComponent>() , MainView`
right?
